medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient, a 60-year-old female, had a 10-year history of stage I mycosis fungoides. Symptoms began 2 years prior with the first tumor on the right labia majora, followed by a second tumor on the left upper medial thigh. Localized electron beam radiation led to complete resolution, but a symptomatic recurrence occurred along the left upper medial thigh. The husband presented 14 months later with tumors on the right arm and leg after a 15-year history of presumed psoriasis.
medical_history.past_medical_history: 10 years of stage I mycosis fungoides. Husband had a 15-year history of presumed psoriasis, with skin biopsies earlier indicating an abnormal lymphocytic infiltrate diagnostic of mycosis fungoides.
medical_history.family_history: Neither partner had a family history of leukemia or lymphoma.
medical_history.social_history: The couple had been married for over 33 years, worked in the healthcare industry, and spent 2 months per year for 15 years at their vacation home in the Caribbean. They lived on the Tennessee River for 25 years downstream from several industrial plants.
